items.title: FAKE: This letter claiming a ban on demonstrations at the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi is…
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
FAKE: This letter claiming a ban on demonstrations at the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi is fabricated

The National Police Service has flagged the letter as fake.

A letter, purportedly authored by the ‘Nairobi Regional Police Commander Augustine Nthumbi’, banning demonstrations at the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi is FAKE.

The letter claims that the ban was effected because the cause for demonstration is an “internal issue” which is “politically motivated”. Further, the letter claims to be addressing a request made to the police force to protect demonstrators at the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi on 15 June 2022.

“This letter notifies that the said demonstrations have been banned by the police force as the Maasai saga is internal issue and is politically motivated by some big shots in Kenya including Governor [sic] of the Central Bank of Kenya Patrick Njoroge whose heard [sic] of cattle have [sic] been evicted from the crater,” the letter reads.

The Tanzanian government has been accused of using force to evict Maasai herders, who live in Ngorongoro District on the eastern edge of the Serengeti National Park. About 150,000 Maasai people living within the Ngorongoro conservation area are set to be moved as the government says overpopulation by the pastoralists and their livestock has led to environmental degradation. The land is important for wildebeest reproduction and migration into Serengeti.

The Associated Press reported that a group of Maasais marched to the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi on 17 June 2022, to demonstrate the eviction of Maasai herders at Tanzania’s Ngorongoro. However, they were dispersed by police using teargas and a national community leader arrested.

Was this letter banning demonstrations at the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi written by the Nairobi Regional Police Commander? We checked and our research led us to a tweet shared by the National Police Service that dismissed the letter we were fact-checking as fake.

“Fake News…!!!” the National Police Service flagged the letter.

We also established that Augustine Nthumbi is no longer the Nairobi Regional Police Commander. An article published by kenyans.co.ke reports that Nthumbi was sent on compulsory leave on 30 January 2022, after the shootings at Mukuru kwa Njenga slums.

On 18 March 2022, the Inspector General of Police Hilary Mutyambai moved Nthumbi to the police headquarters at Vigilance House to take the role of a liaison officer. James Mugera was appointed as the acting Nairobi Regional Police Commander.

PesaCheck has looked into a letter allegedly written by the ‘Nairobi Regional Police Commander Augustine Nthumbi’ purporting that the demonstrations at the Tanzanian Embassy in Nairobi have been banned and finds it to be FAKE.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.

By partnering with Facebook and similar social media platforms, third-party fact-checking organisations like PesaCheck are helping to sort fact from fiction. We do this by giving the public deeper insight and context to posts they see in their social media feeds.

Have you spotted what you think is fake or false information on Facebook? Here’s how you can report. And, here’s more information on PesaCheck’s methodology for fact-checking questionable content.

This fact-check was written by PesaCheck fact-checker Naomi Wanjiku and edited by PesaCheck senior copy editor Cédrick Irakoze and acting chief copy editor Francis Mwaniki.

The article was approved for publication by PesaCheck managing editor Doreen Wainainah.

PesaCheck is East Africa’s first public finance fact-checking initiative. It was co-founded by Catherine Gicheru and Justin Arenstein, and is being incubated by the continent’s largest civic technology and data journalism accelerator: Code for Africa. It seeks to help the public separate fact from fiction in public pronouncements about the numbers that shape our world, with a special emphasis on pronouncements about public finances that shape government’s delivery of Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) public services, such as healthcare, rural development and access to water / sanitation. PesaCheck also tests the accuracy of media reportage. To find out more about the project, visit pesacheck.org.

PesaCheck is an initiative of Code for Africa, through its innovateAFRICA fund, with support from Deutsche Welle Akademie, in partnership with a coalition of local African media and other civic watchdog organisations.

items.title: MISLEADING: This armed robbery captured on CCTV cameras did not take place in Zimbabwe
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
The robbery occurred in Ongata Rongai, Kenya.

This video shared on Facebook claiming to show an armed robbery at Mt Pleasant road in Zimbabwe is MISLEADING.

The caption reads, “This reportedly happened in Mt Pleasant road Harare.”

The robbery caught on CCTV cameras shows masked men following a vehicle as it enters a compound. The masked robbers pounce on the vehicle just before the gate is closed. A woman, who is about to close the gate, is terrified upon seeing the masked men and scatters to safety.

The female driver tries to resist by locking the car’s doors but the robbers use a weapon to forcefully gain entry into it and pull her out. The footage further shows two men taking out valuables in the car while two others force the woman into the house. One of the accomplices is seen harassing her as the others collect valuables.

The video was also shared here and here.

A frame by frame search of the video, however, reveals that the armed robbery took place in the Kandisi area of Ongata Rongai, Kenya, on 13 June 2022. The incident was widely reported by the Kenyan media.

A former policeman is said to be one of the suspects and the Kenya National Police Service, which also highlighted the robbery, called on the public to offer information that could aid investigations.

As of 15 June 2022, some recoveries and arrests related to the robbery had been made.

Four suspects were on 16 June 2022, arraigned in connection with the Ongata Rongai robbery.

PesaCheck looked into a video shared on Facebook claiming to show a robbery that took place in Zimbabwe and found it to be MISLEADING.

items.title: FAKE: This opinion poll on the Siaya gubernatorial race is fabricated
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
The opinion poll contains the branding of Ipsos, but the organisation has disowned it.

An opinion poll shared on Facebook on the Siaya gubernatorial race in the 9 August 2022 election is FAKE.

It contains the branding of Ipsos, a market research company, and ranks the most preferred governor candidate in Siaya County.

The text at the bottom of the image states that the company polled six sub-counties with a sample size of 2,000 people per sub-county between 10 May and 10 June. There is no mention of the year the survey was conducted.

The survey also contains the images of two gubernatorial candidates with their running mates alongside their respective opinion poll results.

Siaya County Senator James Orengo and his running mate, William Oduol, lead the poll with 49 per cent, according to the purported poll.

Former Member of Parliament for Rarieda Constituency Nicolas Gumbo and his running mate, David Ohito, come second in the poll with 45 per cent.

Five per cent of those polled were undecided, it adds.

However, there is no information about the opinion poll on Ipsos’ website, Facebook and Twitter pages, where the organisation posts its opinion survey results.

In an email response to PesaCheck, Samuel Muthoka, the Public Affairs Director in East and Horn of Africa at Ipsos, stated that the opinion poll is fake.

“Ipsos has not carried out any political poll in this 2022 electioneering season,” wrote Muthoka.

PesaCheck has examined the opinion poll shared on Facebook on the Siaya gubernatorial race in the upcoming 9 August 2022 election and found it to be FAKE.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.

By partnering with Facebook and similar social media platforms, third-party fact-checking organisations like PesaCheck are helping to sort fact from fiction. We do this by giving the public deeper insight and context to posts they see in their social media feeds.

items.title: FAKE: This image being passed as DP Ruto’s degree certificate from the University of Nairobi is…
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
FAKE: This image being passed as DP Ruto’s degree certificate from the University of Nairobi is doctored

The UoN has disowned the certificate, terming it fake.

A Facebook post with an image of a degree certificate purportedly from the University of Nairobi (UoN) belonging to Kenya’s Deputy President William Ruto, is FAKE.

The claim was also shared here and here.

The alleged certificate bearing the UoN logo indicates that William Ruto Kipchirchir attained a second class honours (lower division) in Bachelor of Science (Botany). The certificate issued on 22 October 1990, bears the signatures of the vice-chancellor and the deputy vice-chancellor of academic affairs.

The degree certificate in question emerges at a time when political figures, including Nairobi Senator Johnson Sakaja and Machakos gubernatorial candidate Wavinya Ndeti, are under scrutiny over their academic credentials.

As per the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) regulations, candidates eyeing the presidency must meet certain qualifications in order to qualify to appear on the ballot, including being a degree holder from a university recognised in Kenya.

A look at the UoN graduation booklet dated 22 October 1990, shows that Ruto was among the graduates who were conferred with relevant degrees and diplomas. However, Ruto, who was identified as Ruto Kipchirchir William, got upper second class honours and not lower division, as indicated in the claim certificate. He is listed at number 130 under the Faculty of Science.

On 21 December 2018, Ruto was awarded a Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) degree in Plant Ecology from UoN.

The UoN has flagged the degree certificate in question as fake in a tweet dated 17 June 2022.

PesaCheck has looked into a Facebook post with an image of a degree certificate purportedly from the University of Nairobi belonging to Deputy President William Ruto and finds it to be FAKE.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.

items.title: FAKE: This screenshot of a news story claiming Leipzig University dismissed Raila Odinga’s alumnus…
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
FAKE: This screenshot of a news story claiming Leipzig University dismissed Raila Odinga’s alumnus status is fabricated

The screenshot appears as though it was taken from Nation Africa’s website, but the Kenyan publication has disowned it.

A screenshot of a purported news story claiming that Leipzig University in Germany dismissed former Prime Minister Raila Odinga’s alumnus status is FAKE.

The screenshot appears as though it was taken from the Nation Africa website, a Kenyan publication.

The headline of the story reads, “Leipzig University dismisses claims that Raila is their alumni (sic). Says no records show his admission at the institution.”

The time stamp below the headline shows that the article was published on the website on 16 June 2022 at 6:23 p.m.

Below that is an image of Odinga, who is vying for presidency under the Azimio la Umoja One Kenya coalition in the upcoming 9 August 2022 general election.

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC), which enforces elections rules, requires that any presidential aspirant be a holder of a degree from a recognised university in Kenya.

The Facebook post accompanying the screenshot states that Odinga’s candidature hangs in the balance in light of the referenced news reports.

However, there is no information about the news report on the Nation Africa’s Website as claimed.

Instead, a reverse image search of the screenshot returns a story published on Nation Africa’s website containing a similar image of Odinga and published on a date similar to the one on the screenshot. It appears that this is the story whose headline was altered to create the screenshot in question.

Through a Facebook post on 16 June 2022, Nation Africa disowned the screenshot.

“Please be advised that this card doing rounds on social media is fake. Do not fall for fake news,” read the post.

PesaCheck has examined the screenshot of a news story claiming that Germany’s Leipzig University dismissed former Prime Minister Raila Odinga’s alumnus status, and found it to be FAKE.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.

FAKE: This screenshot of a news story claiming Leipzig University dismissed Raila Odinga’s alumnus status is fabricated

The screenshot appears as though it was taken from Nation Africa’s website, but the Kenyan publication has disowned it.

A screenshot of a purported news story claiming that Leipzig University in Germany dismissed former Prime Minister Raila Odinga’s alumnus status is FAKE.

The screenshot appears as though it was taken from the Nation Africa website, a Kenyan publication.

The headline of the story reads, “Leipzig University dismisses claims that Raila is their alumni (sic). Says no records show his admission at the institution.”

The time stamp below the headline shows that the article was published on the website on 16 June 2022 at 6:23 p.m.

Below that is an image of Odinga, who is vying for presidency under the Azimio la Umoja One Kenya coalition in the upcoming 9 August 2022 general election.

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC), which enforces elections rules, requires that any presidential aspirant be a holder of a degree from a recognised university in Kenya.

The Facebook post accompanying the screenshot states that Odinga’s candidature hangs in the balance in light of the referenced news reports.

However, there is no information about the news report on the Nation Africa’s Website as claimed.

Instead, a reverse image search of the screenshot returns a story published on Nation Africa’s website containing a similar image of Odinga and published on a date similar to the one on the screenshot. It appears that this is the story whose headline was altered to create the screenshot in question.

Through a Facebook post on 16 June 2022, Nation Africa disowned the screenshot.

“Please be advised that this card doing rounds on social media is fake. Do not fall for fake news,” read the post.

items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
FAKE: This digital card containing a news alert about a meeting between Mombasa senator and Kenya’s deputy president is fabricated

The digital card contains the branding of Citizen Digital, but the Kenyan news organisation has disowned it.

A purported Citizen TV digital card containing a news alert about a meeting between Mombasa County Senator Mohamed Faki Mwinyihaji and Deputy President (DP) William Ruto is FAKE.

The digital card contains the branding of the Kenyan broadcaster and an image of Mwinyihaji greeting the DP. Text on the top right corner of the digital card indicates that it was shared 65 days to the 9 August 2022 general election.

The Facebook post accompanying the digital card claims that Mwinyihaji, who is defending his Senate seat on an Orange Democratic Movement (ODM) ticket, has sensed defeat in his re-election campaign.

The digital card claims that Mwinyihaji has shelved his ambition in favour of his rival and United Democratic Alliance (UDA) senatorial aspirant, Hamisi Mwaguya.

“Mombasa Senator Faki meets DP Ruto opting to support Hamisi Mwaguya after he encountered rejection at the concluded Mombasa senatorial debate,” reads the news alert.

The senatorial debate referenced in the alert was hosted by Human Rights Agenda (HURIA) on 4 June 2022.

There is no information about the said digital card on Citizen TV’s website, Facebook and Twitter pages, where the broadcaster shares all its bona fide news content.

Through a Facebook post on 13 June 2022, Citizen TV disowned the digital card, terming it fake.

items.title: FALSE: These images of explosions are unrelated to Russia
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
The photos show bombings in Syria, Palestine and Yemen

This Facebook post with images claiming to show a major offensive launched by Russia is FALSE.

The Amharic text posted along a collage of three photos translates into, “Breaking News: Russia launched a major offensive.” The photos show burning buildings.

But as seen here, here, and here, Google reverse image search results reveal that the images are not related to Russia.

The first image was posted on the Workers World website on 17 April 2016. It shows “Saudi piloted U.S. warplanes bombing Yemen’s cities”. The image was published on different websites, as seen here and here.

The second image shows the Israel Defence Force’s (IDF) bombardment in Gaza. The picture was shared on the Ynet website on 14 March 2018. Also, the same image was published on this website on 9 March 2014.

The third image was used on the International Business Times website on 13 July 2015 in an article titled, “Syria: Assad regime barrel bombs kill at least 35 people in Aleppo.”

The description of the photo reads, “Syria: Video shows government forces dropping barrel bombs after denial.” The image is attributed to Reuters.

PesaCheck has looked into the Facebook post with images claiming to show a major offensive launched by Russia and finds it to be FALSE.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.

items.title: HOAX: This poster advertising jobs at KCB Bank is fake
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
The financial institution has disowned the poster and asked the public to disregard it.

A poster submitted for fact-checking via PesaCheck’s WhatsApp Tipline and shared on Facebook advertising employment opportunities at the Kenya Commercial Bank (KCB) is a HOAX.

The poster contains the branding of the Kenyan bank and a claim of openings for full-time employees and interns.

“Our aim is to attract, nurture, develop and retain the most talented people available and support them in expanding their skills and capabilities to ensure that the KCB Group is the destination of choice for the brightest talents in the industry. To achieve this mandate KCB wishes to competitively recruit dynamic, result oriented and self-driven employees and interns to fill the positions for the year 2022,” the poster reads.

The vacant positions include 372 graduate internships, and 170 student internships, 34 accountants, 72 sales and marketing officers, 22 receptionists, 15 office assistants, 12 ICT officers, 11 human resource managers, 37 clerical officers, and 58 drivers.

The qualifications for the positions include prospective applicants possessing a degree, diploma, or a certificate from a recognised institution, being a Kenyan citizen aged 18 years, readiness to work in any part of the country and a candidate’s fluency in English and Kiswahili.

The advertisement also asks prospective job seekers to submit their applications only via a portal, KCB.JOBSPORTAL.CO.KE, as email applications will not be accepted.

However, clicking on the link directs to an imposter KCB website containing a listing of the aforementioned job opportunities.

Clicking on the options under the vacancies section opens an application form asking the applicants to key in their personal information such as name, identification number, gender, level of education, area of residence and the job they are applying for. The form also requires the applicant to pay an application fee of KSh1,000 via a provided mobile money paybill number, which is not standard hiring practice. After paying the money, applicants are to key in the transaction code on the application form, upload their resume and submit the form.

The transaction information shows that the money has been deposited to Prickon Digital Media 1.

The domain name of the impostor KCB website is jobsportal.co.ke, which is not the domain name of the legitimate KCB website which contains the bank’s career page, kcbgroup.com.

The WHOIS information of the imposter website shows that it was registered on 19 June 2022 days after the fake job poster was shared.

On the other hand, the WHOIS information of the legitimate KCB website shows that it was registered on 26 July 2004. Legitimate websites are usually older than impostor websites.

There is no information regarding the job opportunities on the legitimate KCB career page. By the time of publishing this article, the only opportunities listed were Head, Group Operations Audit, Business Development Manager Trade Finance, Audit Manager, Cyber Security, and DevOps Engineer.

Through a Facebook post on 21 June 2022, KCB disowned the recruitment poster.

“It has come to our attention that this post is doing rounds on the internet streets. Please wasee (guys), ignore — this is not us,” read the post.

KCB also directed users to its recruitment portal where it has posted the aforementioned available positions at the bank.

PesaCheck has examined the poster advertising employment opportunities at the Kenya Commercial Bank (KCB), and found it to be a HOAX.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.

items.title: ALTERED: This image claiming to show Senator Johnson Sakaja in a graduation gown is doctored
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
The original image is of a different graduate and is available on a free to use online images resource.

An image submitted for fact-checking via PesaCheck’s WhatsApp Tipline and shared on Facebook claiming to show the Senator of Nairobi, Johnson Sakaja, donning a graduation gown is ALTERED.

The image shows Sakaja holding a document containing the name and logo of Team University, Kampala, Uganda. Besides the image, is a degree certificate purportedly issued by the institution of higher learning.

The image of the degree certificate was shared on Twitter by digital strategist, Dennis Itumbi, who is also the Hustler Nation’s spokesperson. Sakaja, current Nairobi Senator, is vying for the Nairobi gubernatorial seat in the 9 August 2022 general elections under the Kenya Kwanza coalition.

However, the Commission For University Education (CUE) issued a statement on 15 June 2022 revoking its recognition of Sakaja’s degree from Team University. CUE later withdrew the revocation after the legislator moved to court in protest.

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC’s) election rules stipulate that all gubernatorial aspirants must be degree holders. On 19 June 2022, Kenyan news organisations, including The Standard, reported that the IEBC’s Dispute Resolution Committee dismissed a petition brought forth to challenge Sakaja’s clearance to vie for office over his academic qualifications.

A reverse image search of the photo shows it has been published on different websites. One of them is Unsplash.com, an online source of stock images. The image has been digitally altered to include the face of Senator Sakaja. The name of the university which appears on the document held by the graduate, Victor Nzioka, is the University of Nairobi and not Team University, as claimed.

PesaCheck has examined the image claiming to show the Senator of Nairobi, Johnson Sakaja, donning a graduation gown, and found it to be ALTERED.

The image shows Sakaja holding a document containing the name and logo of Team University, Kampala, Uganda. Besides the image, is a degree certificate purportedly issued by the institution of higher learning.

The image of the degree certificate was shared on Twitter by digital strategist, Dennis Itumbi, who is also the Hustler Nation’s spokesperson. Sakaja, current Nairobi Senator, is vying for the Nairobi gubernatorial seat in the 9 August 2022 general elections under the Kenya Kwanza coalition.

However, the Commission For University Education (CUE) issued a statement on 15 June 2022 revoking its recognition of Sakaja’s degree from Team University. CUE later withdrew the revocation after the legislator moved to court in protest.

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC’s) election rules stipulate that all gubernatorial aspirants must be degree holders. On 19 June 2022, Kenyan news organisations, including The Standard, reported that the IEBC’s Dispute Resolution Committee dismissed a petition brought forth to challenge Sakaja’s clearance to vie for office over his academic qualifications.

A reverse image search of the photo shows it has been published on different websites. One of them is Unsplash.com, an online source of stock images. The image has been digitally altered to include the face of Senator Sakaja. The name of the university which appears on the document held by the graduate, Victor Nzioka, is the University of Nairobi and not Team University, as claimed.

PesaCheck has examined the image claiming to show the Senator of Nairobi, Johnson Sakaja, donning a graduation gown, and found it to be ALTERED.

It seeks to help the public separate fact from fiction in public pronouncements about the numbers that shape our world, with a special emphasis on pronouncements about public finances that shape government’s delivery of Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) public services, such as healthcare, rural development and access to water / sanitation. items.title: HOAX: This job alert purportedly by Quickmart supermarket is a scam
items.author: PesaCheck
items.description:
The job application procedure includes paying a fee, which is not a standard recruitment procedure.

An advert shared on Facebook claiming that retail chain Quickmart Supermarket is running a recruitment exercise is a HOAX.

The advert indicates the retail chain is seeking to fill 650 positions including cleaners and guards, technicians, customer care receptionists, storekeepers and cooks, among others.

Prospective job seekers are asked to click on a provided link to submit their applications. Clicking the link directs to a Form containing the branding of Quickmart and further information about the advert.

This time, however, the advert states that the retail chain is seeking to fill 270 positions, contrary to the 650 positions indicated on the Facebook post.

“Quickmart Supermarket is glad to inform the public that we are recruiting new staff across the 14 braches (sic) in Kenya to fill the positions created by the numerous expansion of our stores in the many parts of the country recently.We need more employees in our current and the new branches in the following towns: Nairobi, Nakuru, Mombasa, Kisumu, Eldoret, Kakamega, Nyeri, Kiambu, Kisii,Machakos,Kericho, Nanyuki, Mtito-Andei and Kitale towns,” the message reads.

The message instructs users to ensure that they specify the position for which they are applying for easier classification. It also indicates that the job opportunities offer a salary package from KSh30,000 and above.

“Interested candidates should make their application online.Deadline for application is on Friday 17th June 2022.Interviews are scheduled to take place on Monday 20th June, 2022 subject to government Covid-19 directives.All shortlisted candidates will be communicated on the interview venues.Work is set to start from 23rd June, 2022,” the message reads.

Clicking on the “Next” button directs applicants to another page which requires them to complete the provided application form. The form requires applicants to key in personal information including date of birth, telephone number, email address, location and the job they are applying for.

Applicants are also asked to register for the recruitment with a KSh350 fee paid to the Human Resource Office via a provided mobile money number. The message adds that the amount is to be used for the registration and processing of the interview.

The message further states that the amount is automatically refunded if the applicant doesn’t qualify and that only applicants who have paid the registration fee will be considered.

Once the applicant receives a confirmation message for the mobile money transaction, the instructions require them to fill in the payment code in the application form. The applicants will also also be notified of the interview venues, times and dates, the message adds.

The message states that the confirmation message will show that payment has been made to QUICKMART KENYA STORES HUMAN RESOURCE. However, the actual transaction message reveals that the money was sent to an account with a different name, raising concerns that it could be a scam.

The next step is for the shortlisted applicants to attend the interview, as well as the assessment health test as per ‘Quickmart Stores Rules and Regulations.’ The final step is to sign the contract forms and start working.

There is no information about the job opportunities on the Quickmart supermarket website, its Facebook and Twitter pages where the company posts job openings.

Quickmart has previously asked the public to disregard any job-related posts that are not on the Quickmart website or its official social media pages.

PesaCheck has examined the advert shared on Facebook claiming that retail chain, Quickmart Supermarket, is running a recruitment exercise and found it to be a HOAX.

This post is part of an ongoing series of PesaCheck fact-checks examining content marked as potential misinformation on Facebook and other social media platforms.
